The Emerging Alternative: Dyadic Enforcement & Restoration
Current evolutionary and anthropological perspecetives
Given the apparent rarity of third-party punishment in small-scale societies:
Fitouchi & Singh (2023) argue: “Consistent with the relation-restoration hypothesis, we find that third-party punishment is rare.”
The Emerging Alternative: Dyadic Enforcement & Restoration
Current evolutionary and anthropological perspecetives
Given the apparent rarity of third-party punishment in small-scale societies:
Fitouchi & Singh (2023) argue: “Consistent with the relation-restoration hypothesis, we find that third-party punishment is rare.”
Singh & Garfield conclude: “Our findings suggest that… institutionalized penalties function more to restore dyadic cooperation than to enforce norms.”
The Emerging Alternative: Dyadic Enforcement & Restoration
Current evolutionary and anthropological perspecetives
The Emerging Alternative: Dyadic Enforcement & Restoration
Current evolutionary and anthropological perspecetives
Given the apparent rarity of third-party punishment in small-scale societies:
Fitouchi & Singh (2023) argue: “Consistent with the relation-restoration hypothesis, we find that third-party punishment is rare.”
Singh & Garfield conclude: “Our findings suggest that… institutionalized penalties function more to restore dyadic cooperation than to enforce norms.”
Wiessner (2020) similarly emphasizes restoration: “Emphasis is on amends to the victim for fairness, not punishment of the offender.”
The emerging interpretation:
Norm regulation in small-scale societies is often restorative.
Second-party processes dominate.
Third-party punishment is limited or structurally constrained.
